introduction.p: Suppose that the population of a town is growing continuously at an annual rate of 3% per year.

statement.p: Let P(t) be the population of the town in year t. Write a differential equation that describes the annual growth rate.

hint.p: Small hints for each of the prompts above.

solution.p: Since the population P(t) of the town is growing at an annual rate of 3\% per year, this means that \frac{dP}{dt} = 0.03 P

statement.p: Find the solutions of this differential equation.

solution.p:
We use separation of variables and write \frac{1}{P} \frac{dP}{dt} = 1.03. We then have
\int \frac{1}{P} \frac{dP}{dt} dt = \int 0.03 dt
and thus \int \frac{1}{P} dP = \int 0.03 dt. Evaluating the integrals on each side, we have \ln|P| = 0.03 t + c By definition of the logarithm function, it follows that
|P| = e^{0.03t + c} = e^c e^{0.03t} = C e^{0.03t} . Incorporating the \pm that follows from the abslute value sign into the constant C, we conclude that P = Ce^{0.03t}.

statement.p: If you know that the town's population in year 0 is 10,000, find the population P(t).

solution.p:
Given that P(0) = 10000, we see that 10000 = C e^0 = C. So
P = 10000 e^{0.03t} .

statement.p: How long does it take for the population to double? This time is called the doubling time.

answer.p: The doubling time is t = \frac{\ln(2)}{0.03} \approx 23.105 years.

solution.p:
The population will have doubled when P = 200000. To determine the time it takes the population to double, we solve the equation
10000 e^{0.03t} = 20000 . Thus e^{0.03t} = 2, so t = \frac{\ln(2)}{0.03} \approx 23.105. It will take about 23.1 years for the population to double in size.

statement.p: Working more generally, find the doubling time if the annual growth rate is k times the population.

solution.p:
If the annual growth rate is k, then the differential equation for the population is
\frac{dP}{dt} = kP . We can use separation of variables to show that P = P_0 e^{kt}, where P_0 is the population at time t = 0. We then find the doubling time by solving the equation P_0 e^{kt} = 2P_0. We first solve for e^{kt} and get e^{kt} = 2. Taking natural logs, kt = \ln(2), and dividing by k, t = \frac{1}{k} \ln(2). The doubling time for the population is thus \frac{1}{k} \ln(2).
